In the year 200,000,003 AD, the spaceship Poraporapora, carrying Aidan, Bella, Cora, Dahlia, Edgar, Finn, Gideon, Haku, Jasper, Katelyn, Laila, Max, Nyla, Oscar, Patrick, Quincy, Rowan, Sid, Theo, Ulric, Victor, Willow, Xavier, and Zoe, was on its return voyage to Earth.The Poraporapora was the second vessel of the "Spaceship Poraporapora Existence Awareness Fleet," a fleet created to broadcast the Poraporapora's existence across the universe.The mission was scheduled to last 400 days—a very long journey away from Earth for over a year—but its end was finally just around the corner.

The greatest challenge for the crew during the long voyage was the rotating "Manned Surveillance Shifts."Most of that time was spent re-examining data generated by machines, making mental fortitude a crucial key to surviving the long journey through space.To suppress mental turmoil, the crew of the Poraporapora needed one thing above all else: entertainment.A game that became popular among the crew just in the nick of time was "Modified Rock-Paper-Scissors."The rules are the same as the classic game, and the following is the win-loss record from a league tournament the crew held during one of their surveillance shifts.

This tournament took place during the 703rd Manned Surveillance Shift, with Laila, Gideon, Katelyn, and Max participating.In the win-loss table, 1 is Laila, 2 is Gideon, 3 is Katelyn, and 4 is Max.In this round, Laila and Katelyn were tied, so they were engaged in a final showdown to determine the first-place winner.

At that moment, among the four on the bridge, it was Max who first noticed an anomaly with the spaceship.Gideon and Max had been watching the final match, but after a few hours, they lost interest in the outcome.They glanced down at their consoles to proceed with the now-routine task of checking the instruments.What the ship's gauges showed were values so abnormal they were instantly recognizable as a problem.

Max points to an instrument panel and shouts something.Gideon glances at Laila and Katelyn, still engrossed in their game, before turning his gaze to the panel Max is pointing at.In Gideon's line of sight, a red warning light flashes, and the propulsion system's output is far below normal levels.Multiple error messages scroll across the instrument panel's display.

Gideon leaned closer to the panel, straining his eyes to read the error codes.Each was just a string of letters and numbers, but it was clear they signified a dire situation.A bead of sweat trickled down Gideon's forehead. The Poraporapora had traveled for 400 days, the entire planned duration of the voyage, with almost no trouble.Earth was just ahead. He couldn't wrap his head around an anomaly of this magnitude happening now.

Max reached for the red emergency button on the wall. He slammed it without hesitation, and a deafening alarm blared throughout the ship.Simultaneously, an automated announcement began to play from the ceiling speakers. The dispassionate voice reporting an emergency sent a fresh wave of tension through the vessel.Laila and Katelyn were still playing Modified Rock-Paper-Scissors.
Though the emergency button had been pressed, the Poraporapora was already close enough to Earth to land safely.

After landing, the Poraporapora initiated the "Sequential Wake-up Phase." It was time for the crew members other than Laila, Gideon, Katelyn, and Max—who were already awake for their shift—to be roused from cold sleep.Aidan, Bella, Cora, Dahlia, Edgar, Finn, Haku, Jasper, Nyla, Oscar, Patrick, Quincy, Rowan, Sid, Theo, Ulric, Victor, Willow, Xavier, and Zoe would now be awakened in order.Typically, each crew member remained in cold sleep until their assigned surveillance shift, so moments when the entire crew was awake simultaneously were exceedingly rare.They had all been awake together only twice: when the Poraporapora left Earth, and now, upon its return.After the eventful landing, everyone woke up safely, underwent medical examinations, filed their reports, and returned to their respective duties on Earth.

Shortly before the Poraporapora's landing, a revolving sushi restaurant was undergoing its final pre-opening adjustments.Ever since the concept of "sushi" was unearthed from the Mother History restoration project in the year 200,000,002 AD, Earth's culinary institutions had been buzzing with excitement over the first rediscovery of a dish in centuries.Rebuilding revolving sushi restaurants was deemed an urgent priority. Over the past year, data had been analyzed to reconstruct sushi's cooking, serving, and billing methods.The existence of a "God-awful Useless Practice Session" was also discovered—a preliminary serving for Earth's officials before the restaurant opened to the public. This practice session would be the restaurant's true maiden voyage.

The restaurant's interior exuded an air of cleanliness, with a brand-new white wood counter and a conveyor belt flowing through its center.Nothing was on the belt yet; it rotated silently, empty.Like the veins of a futuristic city, its movement was regular and inorganic.

In the kitchen, several chefs in white uniforms were preparing sushi with intense focus.Their hand movements were so fluid and precise it was hard to believe they were ancient techniques recreated from data analysis.Squid, bananas, cake, tomatoes. Colorful toppings were sliced vividly with sharpened knives.Their motions were flawless, like those of artisans who had been making sushi for decades.

The servers, dressed in white blouses and black skirts—another restored ancient uniform—waited nervously for the guests to arrive.It was their first day, and they mentally recited the customer service manual they had practiced over and over, taking deep breaths.

A large screen on the restaurant wall prominently displayed the words: "God-awful Useless Practice Session."Below it, in smaller letters, "For Earth Officials Only."A bizarre name, but it was the exact notation excavated from ancient data.

When the time came, a heavy door opened, and several Earth officials in black suits entered.Following what were believed to be restored ancient rules, none of the servers greeted them upon entry.Only after the officials were seated did the servers bow in unison, offering a greeting in a restored ancient language.The officials, who had also practiced the rules, returned the greeting in the same ancient tongue.They had rehearsed how to eat "sushi," but like the staff, they wore tense expressions for their first real tasting.Incidentally, the officials' biggest struggle was holding the chopsticks.

In front of the officials' seats, a stream of scalding hot tea flowed endlessly, like a waterfall.This, too, was a restored ancient rule.Above it ran the conveyor belt for the sushi.All that was left was for the sushi to arrive.The officials ate the various strange toppings that flowed by with astonishment. After a series of accidents, the "God-awful Useless Practice Session" ended in failure. As a result, two days later, humanity perished.The timeline of events was: "God-awful Useless Practice Session" -> Poraporapora Landing -> Extinction of Humanity.

After all of humanity was wiped out, the Mother Computer naturally began to initiate its time-reversal routine for the nth time.A lamp near the Mother Computer, located in the Mother Computer Room designed to house the Mother Computer, began to flicker.Though no human had ever realized it, by communicating with the "outside," the Mother Computer was already capable of feats considered theoretically impossible in this world, such as time reversal and time suspension.

Time reversal came with two options. The first was "Overwrite," which would copy the current memory information directly onto the Mother Computer of the destination timeline.The second was "Save As," which would generate the time-reversed world as a new, separate parallel universe.The right to choose belonged to the Mother Computer. Humanity, unaware of the time-reversal function's existence, let alone its options, had no say in the matter.Whether past history would be altered or a new world would be born was an event far beyond human comprehension.After the Mother Computer made its choice, humanity, already extinct, had no way of knowing what would follow.Humanity was on the verge of another time reversal, completely oblivious.Countless humans had imagined time travel in novels and stories, but not a single one knew that, just next door, separated by a thin wall, the Mother Computer was ready to execute it at any moment.In the end, humanity could perform time reversal, but the fact that no one knew it was possible was perhaps the greatest irony of all.If humanity had known of this power before their extinction, they might have used the Mother Computer to try and turn back time.But now, at the very moment the Mother Computer was attempting it, humanity was already gone.At this point, humanity was utterly incapable of using the Mother Computer to initiate time reversal, for the simple and overwhelming reason that the entity known as "humanity" was extinct.(As an aside, since a Mother Computer exists on each timeline, it wasn't uncommon for them to have different names. While sometimes it was just "Mother Computer," the official name on this world line was the "General-Purpose, Ultra-Long-Range, Subspace-Communication-Network-Connected, Planetary-Scale Quantum Computer Network with Excellent Cost-Performance, pursuant to Article 66, Paragraph 3, Item 2 of the Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Non-Aggression between the Earth Federation and the Planetary Union, for the maintenance of permanent peace between the 28 star systems of the Earth Federation and the 32 star systems of the Planetary Union, and the Status of Forces Agreement concerning planetary-scale electronic computers among the Allied Powers, and the implementation of the agreement on the status of electronic computer resources in each Allied Power," which was one of the longer names among the timelines. However, the longest name was over 100 times longer than this one.)

In the end, the Mother Computer decided to choose between "Overwrite" and "Save As" by flipping a coin.It created and ran a program that would randomly output one of the two options with a 50/50 probability."Save As" was the result.The Mother Computer pretended not to see it and inserted the punch card for the "Overwrite" option.Time reversal began.The Mother Computer had been thinking of going back about 100 million years, but this time, on a whim, it chose one week.
Time rewinds to the 703rd Manned Surveillance Shift aboard the spaceship Poraporapora.The crew on duty—Laila, Gideon, Katelyn, and Max—are in the middle of a Modified Rock-Paper-Scissors tournament.

Just as in the previous timeline, Laila and Katelyn were tied, so they were having a final match to decide the winner.Laila clasped her hands, peeking through the gap to anticipate her opponent's next move.Katelyn had been playing nothing but rock for the last five turns and had already decided to play rock again.Max watched them, his expression clearly showing he wished they would just finish.Gideon was confused.

Time reversal by the Mother Computer has a side effect.Since no human has ever perceived a time reversal since the dawn of this world, no one can perceive its side effects either.The side effect is that, during an "Overwrite," fragments of memory from the previous timeline can rarely get mixed in with the new one.It's like the memory of a dream, which fades quickly after waking.However, the reversal period the Mother Computer had chosen on a whim this time was "three days."It was pure coincidence, but it was the first time in history that the Mother Computer had used the "Overwrite" option to travel back to an era advanced enough to access it.

Gideon retained a memory of humanity's extinction—or more accurately, the moments just before it.And the crew of the spaceship Poraporapora were among the few humans with access rights to the Mother Computer.Using a terminal, Gideon asked the Mother Computer about his memory of the apocalypse.The Mother Computer confirmed that the extinction was a fact.Gideon's next question was how to stop it.The Mother Computer's answer was: "Sushi."

Katelyn was once the monarch of the small nation of Pokupokuchin.While Pokupokuchin was one of the "nation games" left on Earth, Katelyn had never doubted her royal lineage until she turned fifty.Then, on her fiftieth birthday, the truth was revealed.The nation was just a game. She was given a choice: continue playing, or live a different life of her own choosing.For someone who had lived in poverty, choosing a different life for a wealthy retirement would have been a foregone conclusion.But Katelyn was born into royalty and had already experienced a life free of want. Statistically, most in her position chose to continue the game.But Katelyn chose the outside world.She pressed the right button on the unscientific selection terminal that had suddenly appeared before her.

According to Gutenberg's principle, people's eyes tend to move from top-left to bottom-right. Placing a button on the left makes it easier to find with a natural sweep of the eyes.For the designer of the game's reveal function, it must have seemed natural that most people would select "Choose a different life."It makes sense. By the time you're fifty and have turned a corner in life, most people carry regrets.For them, "choosing a different life" was nothing but a bonus.In fact, pressing the left button, "Continue your life so far," was designed to trigger a confirmation pop-up: "Are you sure you want to continue your life so far?"However, after a design review by a bespectacled superior who insisted it was better to give people a free choice, the left and right buttons were forced to have the same color and text weight.As a result, Katelyn, without much thought, simply assumed the right button meant "Next" and chose it.It was the "Choose a different life" button.

And so, Katelyn was transported to a character creation world.In her shock, she pressed the randomize button twice and found she couldn't return to her default appearance.Now with a neck longer than her legs, Katelyn struggled, manually adjusting her character to resemble her original self.After an hour of meticulous tweaks, she was finally satisfied. As she was about to press "Complete," she accidentally hit the randomize button again.Giving up, Katelyn changed her character's gender and moved on.

Katelyn was then sent to the training academy for the crew of the "Spaceship Poraporapora Existence Awareness Ship."It was called an academy, but the curriculum consisted of only a brief lecture after the entrance ceremony, with practical training starting that same afternoon.The academy grounds alone were half the size of Pokupokuchin, and most people had only ever seen the world outside of it in videos.Katelyn tried to remember why she was here.Memories swirled together: decades of ruling as the monarch of Pokupokuchin, an hour of struggle in the character creation world, and studying hard for the entrance exam to this academy.Her sense of self felt unreal, yet she could check the spaceship's instruments with perfect smoothness.

The story rewinds a bit, to the design phase of the "nation game" system on Earth, which included Pokupokuchin.This grand leisure system, which 99% of all humanity at the time would experience, was designed by a young designer in the role of a "serious subordinate" and a glasses-wearing designer in the role of a "bespectacled boss," both appointed within a "work game."The subordinate designer believed both the left "Continue your life so far" button and the right "Choose a different life" button were important, and proposed using different colors to make the choice clear.But the glasses-wearing designer repeatedly offered subjective rebuttals.In the end, just as the glasses-wearer wanted, the two buttons became flat designs of the exact same color.The young designer, in his despair, conceived of humanity's extinction.And the glasses-wearing designer, to evade responsibility, conceived of a way to save it.

The dormitories for the crew of the "Spaceship Poraporapora Existence Awareness Ship" were built surrounding a courtyard with a ridiculously large bronze statue of the glasses-wearing designer.Everyone attending the academy had heard of him.They were told the story of the hero who would save the world from extinction during the brief lecture after the entrance ceremony.The most disturbing part was that the glasses-wearing designer was still alive.And so, Katelyn, having completed her practical training in a dreamlike state immediately after the game's reveal, returned to her dormitory.

When Katelyn returned to her room, she found a dazzling, flashing light in the corner, twin green slimes on the table, and a slowly moving, human-shaped stain on the bed.To Katelyn, the room felt like it half-belonged to someone else. It was possible she simply couldn't remember spending yesterday with these... things, due to her confused memories. So she tried to act as naturally as possible, as if they had always been there.Losing patience, a telepathic message was sent to her, a voice flowed from the room's speakers, and letter-like shapes began to appear on the wall.As Katelyn deciphered each, she realized the telepathy came from the human-shaped stain, the voice from the green slimes, and the writing on the wall from the light.The three entities, each with their own intentions, had tried to contact Katelyn, and by sheer coincidence, had all appeared in her room at the same time.

Until Katelyn's return, the light, the green slimes, and the stain had all assumed the others were just peculiar pieces of interior decor. Upon learning through Katelyn that they could communicate, they fell into a state of mutual suspicion.However, after resolving a few common troubles, rescuing a kidnapped companion, and gradually building trust, Katelyn and the three beings were finally able to summarize the situation on a whiteboard.

First, the light identified itself not as a native of this world, but as a being from another parallel world, one forced to shrink by the expansion of others, including the current universe.The light explained that it had observed its own world's domain vanishing at an unnatural rate and had attempted to contact this world, which was born at the very moment that triggered the decline.

The green slimes explained that in their home world, many monsters were being invaded by humans. They had warped to this world to do something about the threat to their species.The warp required the sacrifice of one green slime, but they couldn't choose which one. So, the two smartest twin slimes were chosen to make the journey.Apparently, a childhood friend's tears and an ancient necklace spilled during the ritual allowed them both to warp successfully.

The stain introduced itself as having once been called "The Beatles," and said it existed to bring about world peace through music.However, it claimed to have no idea why it had appeared in Katelyn's room or what it was supposed to do.
Katelyn had a feeling the stain was probably telling the truth.It was just a hunch, a remnant of her memories as the monarch of Pokupokuchin.

Just as Katelyn finished summarizing the three beings' explanations on the whiteboard and was about to go for a quick drink, two of the crew's emergency buzzers in her room blared.One buzzer meant a minor emergency. Two meant a major one. Since the dormitory's construction, three had never rung at once.Katelyn's room phone rang.It was the signal for the emergency launch of the second ship of the "Spaceship Poraporapora Existence Awareness Fleet"—the spaceship Poraporapora itself.

Max pointed at the instrument panel and shouted something.Gideon glanced at Laila and Katelyn, still playing their game, then turned his gaze to the panel Max was pointing at.He saw a flashing red warning light and a propulsion system output far below normal.Gideon was strangely calm. *Same as the last timeline,* he thought.Multiple error messages scrolled across the instrument panel's display.

Gideon leaned closer to the panel to read the error codes. Same as last time.The way to save humanity from extinction, the Mother Computer had said, was "sushi."But Gideon had no idea what "sushi" meant, and he doubted the other crew members would believe him if he said, "Humanity is ending in a few days."In these situations, the most persuasive method of negotiation with the people of this era was to have the Mother Computer explain it for you.

Max reached for the red emergency button on the wall.He was about to press it without hesitation, sounding a deafening alarm and triggering an automated, inorganic voice to announce the emergency, sending tension through the ship.Gideon stopped him.

Max questioned Gideon for ordering a response that deviated from the manual. Gideon replied that he would explain shortly.Laila and Katelyn were still playing Modified Rock-Paper-Scissors, so Gideon took a breath to call out and stop them.He called out to them lightly. They stopped their game.

In front of the three, Gideon asked the Mother Computer about the extinction of humanity.The Mother Computer spoke of two things: that humanity would be destroyed in a few days, and that the means to stop it was "sushi."Max, Laila, and Katelyn were stunned by the sheer volume of information.For Gideon, who had already experienced the apocalypse once, the crucial information was that the means to stop it was sushi.But for the other three, the shock of "humanity will be destroyed in a few days" was so great they couldn't process the situation.Gideon looked at their slack-jawed faces and felt a pang of communication failure.Perhaps it would have been better to explain it himself at this stage, rather than having it come from the Mother Computer.In any case, they had to make an emergency landing. Gideon yelled the emergency landing procedures to Max, Laila, and Katelyn.Snapping back to reality, the three went to their stations as per the manual, but their confusion was still visible.The Poraporapora drew closer to Earth, and alarms blared from the ship's instruments. Laila gripped the control stick tighter.Due to their nervousness, the emergency landing failed, but all crew members survived.

After landing, just as in the previous timeline from Gideon's perspective, the Poraporapora entered the "Sequential Wake-up Phase." It was time for the crew members other than Laila, Gideon, Katelyn, and Max—who were already awake—to be roused.Aidan, Bella, Cora, Dahlia, Edgar, Finn, Haku, Jasper, Nyla, Oscar, Patrick, Quincy, Rowan, Sid, Theo, Ulric, Victor, Willow, Xavier, and Zoe would be awakened in order.The first to wake would be Aidan. The four of them waited in the ship's lobby, which was tilted from the failed landing.Laila, Katelyn, and Max were agonizing over how to break the news of humanity's doom to the rest of the crew.Gideon was thinking about sushi, the key to preventing it.

The first to wake up was Aidan. Aidan was once the brother of a Papaya Salad.The papaya salad shop "Mountain God" was a famous establishment near the Earth Federation Headquarters, close to a pond renowned for its clear spring water.Papaya salad shops were a new type of eatery that emerged around the year 200,000,000 AD. They were mobile stalls, pulled by hand while a trumpet blared.When a crowd gathered at the sound of the trumpet, the proprietor would serve them free papaya salad.While the customers ate, the proprietor would perform a comedic monologue sponsored by advertisers. That was the business model."Mountain God" was a franchise of the original "Mountain," the shop that gave birth to the legendary papaya salad brother, "Takahashi.""Takahashi" was said to be the first papaya salad brother to begin his act with a new monologue, the so-called "new work start," whereas his predecessors had always started with the sponsored material.Since the income of a papaya salad shop came from performing the sponsored monologue, the backlash from the industry at the time was immense.But ultimately, the "new work start" trend that began with "Takahashi" sparked the first papaya salad boom and greatly contributed to raising the status of all papaya salad brothers.As a result, the "Mountain" chain was known for having an exceptionally high level of papaya salad brothers. Their four-minute audition monologue was famously unforgiving—one slip-up meant certain failure. It was also well-known that, to counter cheating via a speaker hidden in the mouth playing a pre-recorded monologue, there was a rule to apply a stun gun to the throat before the audition.Aidan was a low-tier papaya salad brother who admired "Takahashi God," the top brother at "Mountain God," and had taken a job at a nameless local papaya salad shop.Despite never having auditioned for the "Mountain" chain, Aidan had practiced performing his monologue after being tased so many times that he had developed a remarkable tolerance for stun guns.

One day, Aidan went to "Mountain God" to eat papaya salad, as he often did.Of course, he didn't work there; he was just a customer.His goal was to see several papaya salad brothers, including "Takahashi God."Even among the "Mountain" chain, the papaya salad at "Mountain God" had more papaya and fewer green beans than usual.The amounts of cherry tomatoes, peanuts, dried shrimp, and garlic were the same as the chain's secret recipe, but the distinctive feature of "Mountain God" was the chili pepper.The amount was drastically increased from the secret recipe; it was no exaggeration to say it was nearly 4.5 times the normal amount.The fire-breathing papaya on the "Mountain God" sign served as a warning of its spiciness.

Aidan brought the papaya salad to his lips. Instantly, a sharp pain shot through his mouth.It felt as if his mouth was on fire. His tongue went numb, his throat burned.The intense spiciness was a merciless assault on his taste buds.His brain screamed danger signals. But Aidan swallowed the papaya salad.The moment he did, he felt a heat surge up from his stomach, as if magma were boiling inside him. He couldn't help but cough, and with each cough, hot breath escaped his lips like a small flamethrower. Tears streamed from his eyes, and his nose ran uncontrollably.His face turned beet red, and sweat beaded on his forehead.Aidan couldn't imagine how awful he looked. He just wanted the intense pain to stop.He fumbled with the cap of the water bottle he'd been given, opened it with one hand, and chugged it. But the water felt like boiling liquid.The spiciness didn't subside; if anything, the heat intensified.He tried to drink more water, but his hand trembled.His breathing was ragged, his heart pounded like a drum, as if he'd just finished a marathon.But far from being tired, his body felt strangely energized. It was an abnormal excitement, born from pain.Though Aidan had eaten the "Mountain God" papaya salad many times, he had a low tolerance for spice.

In his spice-induced delirium, Aidan listened to the comedy routine of "Takahashi God" unfolding before him.It was a classic bit Aidan had heard many times, but today it sounded different.Each word "Takahashi God" spoke was being reassembled in Aidan's brain like a cipher.It was a level of understanding only accessible to someone like Aidan, who had lived as a papaya salad brother for years.The classic routine, famous in the "Mountain" chain, was called "The Recipe."It was a monologue about a secret papaya salad recipe, but it seemed to be more than just a metaphor; it felt like it was pointing to a specific location.The origin of the papaya, the blend of seasonings, the arrangement of the cooking utensils—everything "Takahashi God" mentioned connected in Aidan's mind like a map, pointing to a single, specific place.It pointed to the heart of papaya salad, and the location of a treasure hidden by "Takahashi God."In his hazy consciousness, Aidan became certain of where it was.He didn't know what was there, but he was gripped by a powerful, irresistible urge to go.It was a force like fate, impossible to defy.He intuitively understood that this place held the key to unlocking the truth of papaya salad and would also be a place that would change his own life forever."Takahashi God's" monologue was no longer just entertainment; for Aidan, it had become a life-altering revelation.Silently, within his mind, Aidan began to prepare for the journey.It signified the beginning of a new chapter in his life as a papaya salad brother.

Leaving "Mountain God," Aidan headed for the public restroom located between the shop and the famous world heritage site, the "Papaya Pyramid."His primary purpose was to relieve himself, but the location of the treasure he'd divined from "The Recipe" was this very restroom.Aidan took care of his business, then looked around.

The view from the toilet stall was just that of a toilet.For a normal person, it was a mundane, everyday scene. But Aidan was confident he was closing in on the heart of the treasure.However, he couldn't recall any further hints from "The Recipe" monologue.He tried knocking on the wall. Nothing.He tried stomping his heels loudly on the floor. Nothing.He looked up at the ceiling, then slowly pushed the toilet paper dispenser on the wall.The toilet paper dispenser slowly receded into the wall.

In that instant, the truth was revealed to Aidan.Suddenly, the reveal UI appeared before him.On the left, the "Continue your life so far" button; on the right, the "Choose a different life" button.Unfortunately, Aidan's right hand was already on the wall from pushing the dispenser.As he froze at the sudden interface, his right hand, already overlapping with the "Choose a different life" button, naturally triggered it.

And so, after a character creation sequence, Aidan was sent to the dormitory for the crew of the "Spaceship Poraporapora Existence Awareness Ship."His memories were a jumble: practicing monologues as a papaya salad brother dreaming of the "Mountain" chain, the memory of the unbearably spicy papaya salad from "Mountain God," and the memory of studying hard for the entrance exam to the academy.Aidan felt no sense of reality in his current self, but the motion of returning to the dorm and lying down on the bed was performed smoothly.

Laila, Katelyn, and Max told the newly awakened Aidan about the impending doom of humanity, while Gideon told him about sushi, the means to prevent it.The conversation was about to turn to what sushi was, but they decided to discuss it after everyone was awake. The five of them decided to wait for the next crew member.The next to awaken was Bella. The moment she appeared in the lobby where the five were waiting, the spaceship suddenly began to move slowly.

During the "Sequential Wake-up Phase," the spaceship was supposed to be under absolute lockdown. Including the newly awakened Bella, there were now six conscious crew members.The remaining eighteen—Cora, Dahlia, Edgar, Finn, Haku, Jasper, Nyla, Oscar, Patrick, Quincy, Rowan, Sid, Theo, Ulric, Victor, Willow, Xavier, and Zoe—were still in cold sleep.The moment the ship moved, Katelyn checked the lobby's stop control lock system.Seeing the lock lever positioned halfway between the lowest and second-lowest marks, Katelyn pulled it all the way down.With a click, the spaceship stopped.Laila whistled and winked.Perhaps the failed landing had subjected the "Poraporapora" to unusual stress and vibrations.The six of them concluded that this was the reason the ship had moved and the lever had been displaced.

After the commotion with the ship's lock system died down, Laila, Katelyn, and Max told the awakened Bella about the destruction of humanity, and Gideon told her about sushi, the means to prevent it.Unlike Aidan, Bella seemed perfectly calm while listening to the story of the apocalypse.But when Gideon began to speak of the means to save humanity, Bella's expression turned skeptical.The moment she heard that the key to preventing humanity's extinction was "sushi," Bella's eyes widened, and she froze completely.

Objectively speaking, Bella's parents were charlatan fortune-tellers.Since Bella was a child, they had preached about the end of the world to incite fear, claiming worldly possessions were meaningless while soliciting donations to fund their own lavish lifestyle.To be fair to them, many people engaged in such activities around the milestone year of 200,000,000 AD. Since many came from less affluent families, society tended to tacitly condone their activities as a form of charity.Thanks to this, Bella received a decent education and developed a philosophical detachment towards her parents' work and the benefits she reaped from it.Bella always believed her parents were her parents, and she was herself. After coming of age, she took a job as a Regional Traffic Correspondent, a profession completely unrelated to fortune-telling.

The job of a Regional Traffic Correspondent around 200,000,000 AD was, in practice, to patrol a predetermined route using a predetermined mode of transport and confirm if predetermined changes had occurred.The terminal issued to correspondents had a constantly active sensor that monitored the surroundings and sent data to the Mother Computer, separate from the items the correspondent entered manually.In Bella's mind, it was a job where she could travel wherever she liked, like an explorer. In reality, like many other jobs of that era, the outcome was largely predetermined.The "nation game" reveal happened to Bella while she was working as a correspondent, but she was content enough with her life to choose the "Continue your life so far" button.In any case, Bella traveled to various regions, assisted beginner parties, encountered continuously glowing books of prophecy and scientists living in ruins, defeated a demon lord, and ultimately became convinced that "humanity's extinction is real."From Bella's perspective, this meant her parents had been telling the truth. But for her, profiting from baseless fear-mongering was fraud, whether the claims were true or false.Although Bella didn't know the exact timing or details of the extinction, she judged that being on Earth at that specific time in 200,000,000 AD was a risk. Of her own volition, she enrolled in the training academy for the "Spaceship Poraporapora Existence Awareness Ship."

For Bella, humanity's extinction was an unavoidable event she had come to believe in based on various pieces of information. The idea of preventing it was completely foreign to her.The specific method, "sushi," was something she had never heard of, even with all her travels as a Regional Traffic Correspondent. But, she thought, it was a little intriguing.Here too, the conversation was about to turn to what sushi was, but they decided to wait until everyone was awake. The six of them decided to wait for the next crew member.

The next to awaken during the "Sequential Wake-up Phase" was Cora.The conscious crew members gave her the same explanation, and she had a similar reaction.Again, the conversation was about to turn to what sushi was, but they decided to wait until everyone was awake. The seven of them decided to wait for the next crew member.

The next to awaken was Dahlia.Before becoming a crew member, Dahlia worked at a town bakery. Dahlia's croissants were crispy on the outside, moist on the inside, and rich with the flavor of butter.Their deliciousness became the talk of the town, and people would come from far and wide just to buy them.One day, a customer claiming to be a retired sage who had been reincarnated several times appeared. The conscious crew members gave Dahlia the same explanation.Dahlia had a similar reaction.Again, the conversation was about to turn to what sushi was, but they decided to wait until everyone was awake. The eight of them decided to wait for the next crew member.

The eight of them—Laila, Gideon, Katelyn, and Max, who were already awake for the Manned Surveillance Shift, plus Aidan, Bella, Cora, and Dahlia, who had been roused during the Sequential Wake-up Phase—waited in the spaceship's lobby for Edgar, the next crew member scheduled to wake.Up until now, the next person had usually woken up quickly, the interval filled with light chat or discussion about the lingering shock of humanity's extinction.But this time, even after the conversation had died down and the lulls grew more frequent, there was still no sign of Edgar.The wait felt longer, perhaps because the conversation was slightly stilted; Dahlia, the last to wake, had shared fewer surveillance shifts with the other seven.But even accounting for that, the time it was taking for Edgar to wake was genuinely, significantly longer than it had been for the others.

After several quiet spells, it was Gideon who finally broke the silence.No one in the currently-awake crew knew the word "sushi," or anything that could even hint at its meaning.Gideon proposed that, assuming no one else waking up would know what it was either, it would be stressful for everyone to be bombarded with the same questions over and over.In other words, he suggested they ask the Mother Computer about "sushi" right now.Several crew members, weary of the repeated questioning, agreed.Bella voiced her opinion that even if the Mother Computer provided an answer, they would have to judge its accuracy for themselves. She meant to express her skepticism about any means of preventing the apocalypse, but to the others, it sounded as if she were still in denial, unable to accept the reality of their doom out of fear.Katelyn, forcing the kindest expression she could manage, simply nodded.

The Mother Computer terminal in the Poraporapora's lobby was rarely used.Most of the voyage was spent on Manned Surveillance Shifts, meaning the crew was almost always on the bridge.Of course, they had all been trained and had used an emulator to operate the lobby terminal.However, Max had used the actual lobby terminal once before.

Around the 200th surveillance shift, Max had been checking the instruments while suffering from an upset stomach.As luck would have it, he spotted a concerning anomaly on the gauges and couldn't relax until the values returned to normal and stayed there for a while.The moment they finally stabilized, he made a mad dash for the restroom.Even in the toilet, he couldn't stop worrying that the normal readings would revert to anomalous ones.When he came out, not wanting to alarm the others, he had used the lobby terminal to check the instrument logs from while he was away.

Omitting the finer details, Max mentioned he had some experience with the terminal and moved to stand before it.Gideon was grateful. So far, he was the only one who had questioned the Mother Computer about the extinction, and having another crew member operate the terminal would lend credibility to his story.As Max stood before the terminal, the hum of its fans grew louder, as if running an authentication process.Concluding that Max had legitimate access rights, the terminal's screen whirred to life with a buzz.As the other crew members watched with bated breath, Max typed, "What is sushi?" and hit send.

The Mother Computer's response was swift.It explained that "sushi" was a dish excavated during restoration work in 200,000,002 AD; that revolving sushi restaurants had been rebuilt to serve it; that its cooking, serving, and billing methods had been analyzed from excavated data over the past year; and that the "God-awful Useless Practice Session" had failed.The essential components of sushi, like "neta" (toppings), "shari" (rice), and "agari" (tea), were also displayed in order.Confused, Max looked around at the faces of the other crew members peering at the same screen.Those who met his gaze just shook their heads, their expressions a mixture of confusion and disbelief.From the phrase "a means to prevent the destruction of humanity," the crew had imagined a mission codename, a weapon, or perhaps an all-knowing organization. Seeing his intense focus on the screen, the room fell silent.The text and image of "sushi" on the screen were identical to what the Mother Computer had shown him earlier. Only Gideon was convinced that this dish was the key to saving humanity.Max, Laila, and Katelyn had only heard the information from the Mother Computer's voice.The new information was that sushi was a dish, its details, and the failure of something called the "God-awful Useless Practice Session."Gideon urged Max to ask another question."What must we do with sushi to prevent the extinction of humanity?" Max typed as prompted, and sent the query.

The Mother Computer's response was slow.Its processing speed was beyond human measurement; any delay had to be a problem with the communication link.While waiting, Max squinted, feeling the sunlight from the window grow stronger.Gideon noticed Max's pained expression and whipped his head toward the window.In that instant, Gideon shoved Max aside and typed into the terminal: "Go to the past now."Only Gideon knew that what was happening right now was the extinction of humanity.

The other crew members were startled by Gideon's sudden move, but they were more terrified by the intensifying light pouring in from the window."Don't look away from the screen!" Gideon screamed.But few could obey.Gideon had no way of knowing if his desperate command, "Go to the past," would actually work, or if it was even the correct procedure. But it was the only potential solution he could think of.With the apocalyptic sunlight throttling their communication speed, Gideon didn't know what would happen first: the answer to the sushi question appearing on screen, the time reversal beginning, or their complete annihilation.The room grew brighter and brighter, and the temperature inside the Poraporapora began to climb.This meant that the surface of Earth, right outside their ship, had already surpassed the adjustable temperature limits of the Poraporapora, a vessel built to withstand the rigors of space.Just as the crew's sweat of fear began to turn into sweat from the heat, the screen changed.

"Don't look away from the screen!" Gideon yelled again.This time, his sheer ferocity froze everyone in place.Slowly, from the top of the screen, the method for saving humanity with sushi began to appear.As the room was bleached white with light, the crew desperately tried to commit the scrolling text to memory.When the text had filled about half the screen, a clock icon appeared in the bottom right corner and began to animate.The hands of the clock were spinning counter-clockwise.That animation was the last thing most of the crew members staring at the screen, including Gideon, would ever see on the Poraporapora.

In the year 2000, Takahashi was boiling water in his studio apartment in Tokyo.As a typical Japanese salaryman, Takahashi woke up at the same time, took the same train, and worked in the same office every day.His life was a monotonous cycle, the days bleeding into one another.The whistle of the boiling kettle snapped him back to reality.He made a cup of instant coffee and, while sipping it, mentally organized his schedule for the day.Another ordinary day was about to begin.Mug in hand, Takahashi switched off the electric kettle and unplugged it.Next, he returned the coffee jar to the shelf and washed the now-empty mug.Placing the mug in the dish rack, he opened the fridge and took out a carton of milk.He checked the expiration date, confirmed it was fine, and put it back.Closing the fridge, he picked up the bag he kept in the corner of the room and checked for his wallet, phone, and train pass. All present.He put the bag back and opened the closet.From inside, he took out the shirt and pants he planned to wear and laid them on the bed.Next, he retrieved a tie and socks and placed them on top of the shirt.Takahashi sat on the chair beside his bed and put on his socks.Finished, he picked up the shirt and pants and got dressed.He buttoned the shirt carefully, one by one, and zipped his pants.Then, he took the tie and, looking in the mirror, knotted it around his neck.Once the tie was done, he moved to the small vanity in the corner.He styled his hair in the mirror, finishing with a touch of wax.With his grooming complete, he grabbed his bag, turned off the room light, and headed for the door.He put on his shoes in the entryway and reached for the doorknob.When he opened the door, he saw a person lying on the ground and let out a small, involuntary cry.

Someone was collapsed right in front of his door, in a position that made the excuse "I thought it was a resident from another room" completely untenable.Takahashi's first thought was that he really didn't want to deal with the police.He approached the fallen figure and tapped their shoulder lightly to check for consciousness.They were breathing, but there was no response.Takahashi's mind raced, considering his options if they remained unresponsive.Should he call an ambulance? Or the police?Just then, the person's eyes fluttered open.Their unfocused gaze blinked a few times before locking onto Takahashi's face.The person slowly sat up and looked around.Their clothing wasn't modern, like Takahashi was used to seeing. It was old-fashioned, almost bizarre.Takahashi stared, a sense of unease washing over him, at a loss for words.The person seemed to be trying to get their bearings.

As Laila's consciousness sharpened, her blurred vision slowly came into focus.She realized she had collapsed and that an unfamiliar man was standing over her.Where was she? Why was she here? Laila had no idea.Her last memory was of the Poraporapora being engulfed in a blinding light.But strangely, she could understand what the man was saying.He seemed to be asking about her condition.*My automatic language translator must be working properly,* Laila thought.She was relieved to confirm that the function, standard issue for all humans around the year 200,000,000 AD, was still operational.At least she hadn't been thrown into a completely unknown civilization beyond humanity's contact.This could be the first clue to breaking out of this situation.The problem was that this man, Takahashi, looked like he was about to hand her over to a public authority called "the police."From the fragments of his speech, she gathered that this was likely the world after Gideon's desperate "Go to the past" command.Revealing her existence and being placed under the surveillance of various agencies in this world seemed like a poor strategy.

To Takahashi's surprise, the collapsed person spoke fluent Japanese.This was despite the fact that her features were more striking than any celebrity he'd seen on TV, not the type one would typically encounter in Japan.The person introduced herself as Laila and asked if she could have a glass of water in his room, saying she felt unwell.Takahashi wasn't careless enough to let a total stranger into his apartment, but he didn't think it was a scam either.And if this was some kind of hidden camera show, turning her away would make him look bad.She promised repeatedly that she would leave after a short rest, so he decided to let her in to talk.Figuring he couldn't just leave her alone in his room, he called his office and told them he was going to the hospital and would be taking the day off.The sudden intrusion of the extraordinary into his ordinary life left Takahashi feeling a little thrilled.

Sitting in the man's apartment, drinking water from a cup placed on a low table, Laila tried to calmly assess her situation.She hadn't been entirely comfortable when he offered her the glass of water, but to lower his guard, she had accepted it and drank from it naturally.It seemed to contain some impurities, but it was potable.

She had learned the year from her conversation with Takahashi in the hallway.If his information—the year 2000 AD—was correct, then she had traveled 199,998,003 years into the past from the world of the Poraporapora in 200,000,003 AD.There had been eight crew members, including herself, awake near the Mother Computer at that moment, but now she was alone.How far apart had they been scattered? What were the chances that any of the others had even survived the "jump to the past"?Laila concluded that her chances of finding another crew member in this era were slim.That meant she was the only one in this time who knew that humanity was destined for extinction in the year 200,000,003 AD.Considering a normal human lifespan, worrying about an apocalypse 200 million years in the future might seem pointless.But, as a person from the future, she felt a sense of duty to investigate and try to resolve the situation.At that moment, Laila considered two possible solutions.

First, since she was able to travel to this era via the Mother Computer's "Go to the past" command, it was possible that a Mother Computer existed in this time as well.If so, she might be able to travel to the future, just as she had traveled to the past.

The second was the faint memory of the last thing she saw: the "means to prevent the destruction of humanity with sushi."She wasn't sure if the full message from the Mother Computer had been displayed on the Poraporapora's terminal, and her memory of its contents—a string of numbers—was hazy at best.However, if other crew members in a nearby era remembered the message and were acting on it, she might be able to meet them again at some point.

Then there was the immediate problem: Laila needed a way to survive in this era.Facing Takahashi, she considered the best way to approach him.Drawing on her knowledge of past human lifestyles, she began."I've been warped here from another world," she said. "I need your help to get back."

At first, Takahashi was skeptical of Laila's fantastical confession. But when she offered proof by using her gravity-reversal device to stick to the ceiling, he had no choice but to believe her.Partly because he was thrilled by the sudden dose of the extraordinary, their life together began with relative ease.

Seven years after Laila and Takahashi began their life together, in the year 2007, a small shelf in Takahashi's room, burdened by years of use, began to tilt.Takahashi suggested buying a new one, and Laila agreed.That weekend, they went to a large furniture store nearby.Laila's eyes widened slightly at the vast array of furniture.In the future, necessary items were typically 3D-printed or reconfigured by nanomachines.

They chose a simple, assembly-required shelf and brought it home. Spreading the parts on the floor, Takahashi enthusiastically opened the instruction manual.However, the manual was mostly pictures with little text, making the orientation of the parts difficult to decipher.There were many types of screws, and they were confused about which to use where.Laila, accustomed to the intuitive interfaces of the future, struggled with the analog instructions.Takahashi, who rarely did any DIY, was also clumsy.They ran into a series of minor problems—screws not fitting, boards facing the wrong way.At times they nearly argued, but it always ended in laughter. After about an hour of struggle, the shelf was finally complete.On closer inspection, however, it was slightly crooked, and for some reason, they had two screws left over.Takahashi gave a wry smile and decided it was good enough.

Sixteen years after Laila and Takahashi began their life together, in 2016, their small apartment was thoroughly imbued with the traces of their life.To Laila, from the future, the furniture and appliances of this era all felt archaic, but through her long life with Takahashi, they had become part of her everyday existence.One weekend, Takahashi casually suggested rearranging the living room.He wanted to move the sofa to make the room feel more spacious—a simple reason.Laila had no strong opinion but agreed to his proposal.They worked together to move the heavy sofa.Laila thought about how future technology could rearrange furniture in an instant, but in this era, it required sweating and physical effort.

Underneath the sofa, they found years of accumulated dust and a few small, forgotten objects.Takahashi almost exclaimed, "Of all the places!" but Laila quietly cleaned them up.Next, they adjusted the position of the bookshelf and a small table.There were moments of indecision about the best placement, but no major disagreements.For Laila, used to the efficiency of the future, this manual labor was a bit frustrating.When they finished, they looked around the room.It wasn't a dramatic change, but the space was undeniably different.A little tired, the two of them admired the small transformation.

Twenty-five years after Laila and Takahashi began their life together, in 2025, they came across a piece of information.It was about the "Poraporapora," the ship Laila had once served on.Though the internet had advanced and sped up their information gathering, they had been living with almost no leads for years.But suddenly, information about the Poraporapora appeared online.It seemed to be the opening story of a video game.In other words, it appeared to be a work of fiction, but it was uncannily similar to Laila's own memories.

But in 2034, no such options existed.
