After the awkward meal, Saito led the three of them to the communal cemetery.Among the neatly arranged plots, one, particularly old yet carefully tended, was Max's grave.There, along with various items reminiscent of his life in the shelter, was an old box.A faint label on the box, written in a language the crew could understand, read: "To everyone from the Poraporapora."As Cora and Gideon nervously opened the box, they found a set of Poraporapora crew equipment and a data terminal inside.

The data terminal, presumably left by Max, was playable with the crew equipment they had.The three of them held their breath and played the terminal.It contained a record of Max's life in this shelter.According to the record, Max had introduced the concepts of record-keeping and education, which had been lacking in this society, by fusing the shelter's technology with his future equipment.This was to ensure that when his comrades from the past eventually arrived at the truth, the shelter's technology would be capable of accessing the Mother Computer.After viewing the entire record, the three stood speechless.They understood that the currently accessible Mother Computer was the grand hope that Max had left behind, believing in his future comrades and in humanity.Cora faintly remembered from a distant memory that the pale blue light that had transported Max and Gideon was similar to the process by which her substitutes had been transported to the Mother Mother Company's warehouse.Cora and Gideon silently vowed to carry on Max's will, and Saito, learning the truth about the hero, also resolved to cooperate.

Having learned of Max's last wishes and the unexpected truth of their world, the three left the cemetery and headed back to the Mother Computer room.As they walked through the sterile corridors of the shelter, Gideon, Cora, and Saito tried to organize and integrate the information they had each gathered.Only their footsteps echoed in the shadows cast by the regularly spaced lights.For a while, there were no words between them.Each was contemplating the fragmented yet significant information they had obtained from the Mother Computer.The year 10,000, an impossibly distant era. The unidentified "bug" said to be the cause of humanity's extinction.And the inexplicable word "sushi" that would sometimes overwrite everything else.These felt less like clues to a solution and more like entrances to an even deeper labyrinth.

It was Saito who spoke first. He reviewed, one by one, the information he and Cora had obtained from the Mother Computer.The concept of the Christian calendar, the meaning of the word "bug"—these were all new to Saito, but he tried to commit each piece of information to memory earnestly.The information was consolidated into a few unshakable facts.This world is the year 10,000 AD. Listening to Cora, Gideon realized that her intuition strangely aligned with a question he had been pondering.He brought up two mysteries that he had mulled over during his time alone on the deserted island.The first was about the incomprehensible string of numbers that had flashed on the screen in the final moments of the Poraporapora, as it was engulfed in light.Gideon had recorded the numbers from memory onto his survival kit's data terminal.Hearing this, Cora remembered that she had also jotted them down on her arm so as not to forget. After confirming that the young designer was completely gone, the three emerged from the shadows and began their all-night investigation.Bella operated the computer, analyzing the logs from the keylogger she had planted, while Gideon and Cora meticulously went through the piles of documents on the desks and shelves.They succeeded in viewing the world's blueprint: the specifications for "Nation Game," concept art, and a massive volume of development logs.What was written there was the full picture of a grand simulation game, designed with incredible detail.

The unanswerable questions weighed heavily on their hearts.

Katelyn had left Laila and was walking towards the station.At her feet, the twin green slimes followed as if gliding over the ground. Around her, the slowly moving human-shaped stain and the dazzlingly flashing light floated, each maintaining a certain distance.According to the information from Laila, an artificial structure—a station—should be ahead, but no matter how far she walked, the scenery remained a monotonous landscape of rice paddies and distant mountains.

After walking for about an hour, Katelyn found an old wooden bench by the side of the road.Although she was anxious about the unknown distance to her destination, she decided to take a break, considering her accumulated fatigue.

As Katelyn sat on the bench, the accompanying light slightly changed its blinking rhythm.Focusing on the change in the light, Katelyn recalled the final moments of the Poraporapora.Gideon's desperate command, "Go to the past."And the animation of the clock's hands spinning backwards on the screen.What was that phenomenon? And could it be triggered intentionally again?Now that she had decided to continue her investigation, she needed to think about the means.As if reading her thoughts, letters slowly began to appear on the wooden backrest of the bench, where nothing had been written before, as if branded there.It was a means of communication with the light.

The information conveyed by the light was astonishing, fundamentally overturning Katelyn's understanding of things.According to the light, Gideon's "Go to the past" on the Poraporapora was not, strictly speaking, an act of traveling back in time.It was merely a process of moving to a different data instance within this world.The light then began to disclose to Katelyn the set of regulations that normally had to be followed to execute this transfer process.

Katelyn stared blankly at the emerging text.First, to perform a time transfer, one must purchase a "Time Transfer Ticket" from an "Administrator" in advance.Furthermore, "Option Tickets" for specifying the destination time and place also existed, but these had to be purchased separately at almost the same time as the transfer ticket.The purchased tickets had to be handed directly to the administrator before the transfer process began.If multiple transfer processes were requested simultaneously, they were processed on a first-come, first-served basis, and later arrivals had to form a queue outside the process.At the start of the process, a verbal identity and intent confirmation would be conducted by the administrator.Answering before the administrator finished their question, a so-called "flying answer," was strictly forbidden.The administrator would ask for preferences on three items: "Timeline Density," "World Stability," and "Intervention Level." It was customary for users to answer "Normal" to all unless there was a special reason.An incorrect answer or a response in a non-standard format would be rejected.There was also a five-second time limit to respond to each question.The regulations continued.During the time transfer process, any private conversation or use of personal terminals was not permitted.If such acts were discovered by the administrator, the process would be immediately terminated, and the user would be forcibly removed from the facility.Once a process had started, it was impossible for the user to interrupt it or cancel purchased options; it had to be completed to the end.Users in the process were required to refrain from actions that would disturb others, such as talking loudly or making noise.And finally, it was mandatory for the user to return all instruments used in the time transfer process to their original positions and to clean the console with the provided cloth as part of the complete process.

The sheer volume and complexity of the regulations made Katelyn feel slightly dizzy.She couldn't determine if these rules applied only to the light's original parallel world, or if they were an alternative method to be used when specifying "Go to the past" to the Mother Computer was not possible.For that matter, she didn't understand how Gideon had been able to type "Go to the past now" with such conviction in that moment on the Poraporapora.Just then, Katelyn realized she had overlooked something important.Relieved at her reunion with Laila, she had completely forgotten to consider the possibility of contacting other crewmates using the stain's telepathic ability.She immediately spoke to the stain, asking if it could contact someone else.A moment later, the stain telepathically informed her that it had made contact with Gideon.

In the quiet conference room after the young designer had left, Gideon, Bella, and Cora were solidifying their next course of action.The monitor of the designer's computer displayed a vast amount of data, the very blueprint of the "Nation Game" world.The three decided to put aside any concrete actions to save their world for the time being and to prioritize uncovering the true nature of the "bug" that was the source of all their troubles.

Bella focused on the records from the keylogger she had planted on the work computer.The history of commands executed by the young designer at first appeared to be a meaningless string of characters.His operations had been cleverly disguised to leave no trace in the system logs, making it nearly impossible to decipher his intent through normal analysis.However, the pattern of operations seemed to Bella to strangely correspond with an ancient civilization's cryptographic protocol she had once deciphered as a Regional Traffic Correspondent.Bella's fingers flew across the keyboard, reconstructing the fragments of the young designer's thoughts from the vast logs.Soon, it became clear that the core of his operations was focused on the "sushi" entry in the system's food culture database.But the logic showing a direct causal link between that data and the world's survival remained elusive.Bella could only intuit that the series of operations was designed to intentionally place an excessive load on the system's core, particularly on the unimplemented modules that simulated senses like taste and touch.

While watching Bella's analysis, Gideon's thoughts turned in a different direction.He would leave the identification of the bug to Bella. The problem was how to apply a patch to their own world.The Mother Computer, with its authority to freely move through timelines, must have privileged access to this simulation world.Executing a fix program created by Bella via the Mother Computer to directly rewrite the laws of the world seemed like the most reliable method. But there, Gideon's thoughts hit a snag.From the "Nation Game" documents, they had determined the current year was 2206.But there was no clue anywhere as to whether the technology to access the transcendent entity known as the Mother Computer existed in this era.

Cora's attention drifted from the discussion to a logo on one of the scattered documents.It was for an operating system called "N-OS," but the design was familiar to her.It was identical to the logo she had seen every time she operated a control terminal in the "Mother Mother Company's warehouse," the facility founded by Papacola, isolated from the outside world.She didn't know why, but fragments of her memories from her time in the facility began to resurface.

For Cora, life in the facility had been a monotonous routine.Cora and the dozens of "substitutes" who shared her face.Their main job was to take turns being brain-scanned, but their free time was relatively unrestricted.The facility had a huge library, but it was filled only with technical books and academic papers; there wasn't a single work of fiction or entertainment.One day, Cora did something different from the other substitutes. The memory of failing to create a cake and producing a tasteless, sand-like lump was not enough to dull Cora's spirit of inquiry.Rather, the complete failure prompted her to turn her attention to other possibilities.The facility's library archived not only data on material composition but also vast amounts of text on acoustics and music theory.Reproducing taste, a complex chemical reaction, might have been beyond the capabilities of the facility's automatons.But sound was just vibrations in the air, physical waveform data.Compared to creating matter from scratch, controlling the frequency of energy already flowing through the existing equipment seemed far more feasible.

Cora once again accessed the debug console hidden deep within N-OS.She focused on the large-scale air circulation system that ran 24/7 to maintain the facility's environment.The operating noise of the giant fans that circulated air through countless ducts was a constant, low-frequency hum that usually went unnoticed.Cora thought that by subtly and periodically changing the rotational speed of these fans, she could control the vibration of the air flowing through the ducts—in other words, the pitch.From the library, she found the sheet music data for an ancient nursery rhyme with the simplest structure and spent several weeks building a program to convert its musical scale information into a sequence to control the fans' rotation.

On the day of execution, Cora waited in the facility's central living area.At the designated time, the facility fell silent. The strange sound reached the ears of the few remaining substitutes who were performing their routines in various parts of the facility.As if on command, they all stopped what they were doing at the exact same moment.One was about to bring a paste of nutrient food to their mouth, another was just about to put on a headset for a brainwave scan—their movements completely frozen.They didn't look for the source of the sound, but simply stared at a single point in the void.On their unchanging, expressionless faces, a faint, almost data-error-like hint of confusion appeared.Eventually, the performance ended, and the air circulation system returned to its normal operating hum.The substitutes, too, resumed their interrupted actions as if nothing had happened.The facility returned to a complete, uncreative silence.

The two failures engraved a single, clear understanding in Cora's mind.The facility known as "Mother Mother Company's warehouse," and the N-OS system at its core, were not suited for "creating" new things.It was a completely closed system, designed only to "reproduce" given information according to a given procedure, without the slightest deviation.She remembered the sense of incongruity that occurred when trying to process unexpected information, whether given from outside this closed world or generated from within.That systemic rejection, her intuition told her, might be the true nature of the phenomenon they were now calling a "bug."

Cora slowly stood up. Just then, Gideon received a telepathic message from the stain.It was a message from the stain, relaying a message from Katelyn.

Katelyn could sense the three of them discussing on the other side of the telepathic link.Gideon suggested the possibility that it was a trap set by the Mother Computer.Cora countered, based on her experience and intuition, that the Mother Computer would never engage in such deceit.Gideon argued logically that sushi had to be one or the other—either the "bug that destroys the world" or "something that saves it," but it couldn't be both.Finally, Bella proposed the safest course of action: to freeze all activities related to "sushi" at present and completely eliminate the risk of extinction.

Listening to their debate, Katelyn looked down at the bench in front of her.As she mulled things over, the light accompanying her changed its blinking rhythm, and letters slowly began to form on the wooden backrest of the bench.The content was a guideline that addressed the question Katelyn had and the problems the three had raised.Katelyn relayed the idea presented by the light, almost as if it were her own, to Gideon and the others through the stain.

The proposal was that it was impossible to determine at present whether "sushi" was a bug or not, and that they should wait and see, observing the actions of the simulation world's designers, especially until the release of "Nation Game."The eras Katelyn and the others were in, if they were part of a simulation, were already fixed events.
